On May 25, Minneapolis police officers arrested George Floyd after a deli employee called 911, accusing him of buying cigarettes with a counterfeit $20 bill. Seventeen minutes after the first squad car arrived at the scene, Mr. Floyd was unconscious and pinned beneath three police officers, showing no signs of life.

Even as George Floyd called out for help, a Minneapolis police officer kept his knee on his neck for eight minutes and 46 seconds. Tomorrow morning at 10:15am at the link below, our Phoenix community will come together to honor George Floyd's life and the many that have been lost before him with eight minutes and 46 seconds of silence - the length of time it took for a police officer to kill a black man in America.

We invite you to join us on the Phoenix Network Facebook page as we will be going live at 10:15am. https://www.facebook.com/PhoenixCharterSchools/

Last week, the Harvard Latino Men's Collective hosted a panel discussion on mass incarceration and the ways in which it affects the Black and Latinx community. Panelists include Dr. Cornel West, Dr. Kristina Shull, Arthur Bembury, Douglas Rogers, and Phoenix Chelsea student, Orlando Lopez.

Orlando shared his experience as a young immigrant from Guatemala, his firsthand experience with ICE, and the hope he has for change in the way that the Black and Latinx communities are treated and supported in the United States in the future.

A big thank you to Latino Men's Collective for hosting Orlando on the panel!
